title: 103_hr3464
content: The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes funds for the modernization of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System. The Forest Service will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Increased criminal penalties for arsonists are also included in the Act. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" includes amendments to federal law regarding the malicious use of fire or explosives. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment up to 10 years, with increased penalties for damages exceeding $1,000,000 or causing harm to individuals. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" imposes penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives. Offenders can face fines and imprisonment ranging from 5 to 40 years based on the extent of damage or harm caused. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" imposes penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives, including fines, imprisonment up to 25 years, and the possibility of the death penalty. Amendments to the law also address interstate commerce related offenses with fines or imprisonment up to 10 years. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment of 5 to 20 years. If the offense places a person's life in jeopardy or the damage exceeds $10,000,000, the penalty is a fine and imprisonment of 8 to 30 years. If personal injury occurs or the damage exceeds $25,000,000, the punishment is a fine and imprisonment of 10 to 40 years. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $25,000,000, the offender shall be subject to a fine and imprisoned for not less than 10 nor more than 40 years. If the death of any person results, the offender shall be subject to a fine, imprisonment for any term greater than 25 years (or life), and also be subject to the death penalty. Reckless or negligent use of fire or explosive resulting in destruction of a dwelling or harm to a person carries penalties under section 844 of title 18, United States Code. If someone maliciously destroys a dwelling or injures a person, they can be fined or imprisoned. If convicted, they must perform community service. Juveniles may also face confinement and community service for similar offenses. The text discusses penalties for engaging in prohibited conduct, with fines or imprisonment for malicious acts. Defense conversion will be used to enhance private firefighting capabilities. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, will report to Congress on utilizing excess military cargo and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, they will explore reforming Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of planes for fire fighting. SEC. 7. The Forest Service will study building roads and backup power supplies to ensure water availability for fire fighting in national forest areas. The results will be reported to Congress within a year. SEC. 8. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
